question: Question_07
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Full-Solution Problems.} In questions 2-8, justify your
answers and \textbf{show all your work.} Simplification of answers is
not required unless explicitly stated.}\\Let

\begin{align*}f(x)= \begin{cases}
4x-\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3x-3}-1, & \textrm{if} \; x<1, \\
2x+1, & \textrm{if} \; x\geq 1.
\end{cases}\end{align*}

Use the definition of the derivative to find \emph{$f'$(1)} or
show that \emph{$f'$(1)} does not exist.
sols:
Using the definition of a derivative, we see that
$f'(1) = \lim_{x \to 1}\frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1}$

Since the functions differ on either side of 1, we will want to use one
sided limit to attempt to evaluate the limit. If the one sided limits
are equal, then the derivative exists. Otherwise, the derivative does
not exist. Firstly, notice that $f(1) = 2(1)+1 = 3$. From the left, we
have

\begin{align*}
\lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1} &= \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{4x-\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3x-3}-1-3}{x-1}\\
&=  \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{4x-4}{x-1} - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3(x-1)}}{x-1} \\
&=  \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{4(x-1)}{x-1} - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3(x-1)^2} \\
&=  4 - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3(x-1)^2} \end{align*}

Now, to evaluate the last limit, recall that
$\lim_{x \to 0} \frac{\sin(x)}{x} = 1$ hence
$\lim_{x \to 1} \frac{\sin(2x-2)}{2x-2} = 1$ and so, multiplying top and
bottom by 4, we have

\begin{align*}
\lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1} &=  4 - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3(x-1)^2} \\
&= 4 - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{4\sin^2(2x-2)}{3\cdot 4(x-1)^2} \\
&= 4 - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{4\sin^2(2x-2)}{3\cdot (2x-2)^2} \\
&= 4 - \frac43 \left( \lim_{x \to 1^-} \frac{\sin(2x-2)}{2x-2}\right)^2 \\
&= 4 - \frac{4}{3} \\
&= \frac{8}{3}\end{align*}

As for the other side, we have

\begin{align*}
\lim_{x \to 1^{+}}\frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1} &= \lim_{x \to 1^{+}}\frac{2x+1-3}{x-1}\\
&=  \lim_{x \to 1^{+}}\frac{2x-2}{x-1} \\
&=  2 \end{align*}

As the left and right hand limits do not agree, we have that the
derivative does not exist at 1.
